great thanks so much Shree and thanks everybody for having us here
my name is nithya Ramanathan and I'm the CEO of next leaf analytics we are an IOT
and data analytics company we are a non-profit and we essentially work to
bring sensor and data technologies to address some of the biggest public health and environmental challenges out
there so I'll share a little about what we've learned in deploying technologies
at scale in a number of countries around the world our target countries are the 80 poorest countries but first I want to
take a quick step back and just talk about what are the broader trends and
where are we going as a planet as in a global economy and for us what we think a lot about our sort of where do the
customers of tomorrow live and it's really going to be in places like this
so we know that the Chinese middle class is growing quickly and you know for example in asia-pacific the middle class
is going to be growing in the next decade or two by over 5x and so as we
think about how emerging markets are going to be driving the global economy one of the things that that we see is
that it's really going to be important to start looking at not only the products that customers are buying but
also importantly the regulations that are being put in place in countries and these will actually have tremendous
impact on climate change global poverty and health and and why does this all
matter well we see a real opportunity we've been working we've been around for about 10 years and we've seen how
spectacularly development solutions can fail fail when they don't think about
who the customers are what are the local context and how you design for sustainability so in order to give you
an example actually from my own life I'll give you a little bit of how I kind
of came to this work so I started my PhD in computer science back in 2003 and
this was actually where I did my thesis work so Bangladesh I got really lucky my
advisor was one of the early internet pioneers and had unlimited resources so I got to define my own computer science
challenges and problems and I worked in what we now know is IOT back then was called distributed sensor networks and I
wanted to understand why there was so much arsenic poisoning in the groundwater in Bangladesh so I put out a
bunch of sensors got a bunch of data wrote some great papers and at the end
the women in the village were like oh we're so glad you're here you're gonna help us solve this problem and I thought
oh crap no I haven't done anything I've written some papers and so I then went
and I raised $5,000 to to help build a well in the village I you know we all
fell great okay we're gonna help this one village at least you know get access to clean water and I got on the plane
back home and I had my first realization I thought wait who's going to fix this
well when it breaks where are they gonna go for a replacement part how do I even know that this is the right well for
this village and I started asking myself all these questions that really today to
date still very few people are asking about development sector innovations so too often when we think about affecting
change in water and health it's still this sort of charity mindset of handing out free stuff that doesn't have a
long-term sort of sustainable model behind it so when my co-founder Martin luk√°cs and I who'd been doing our PhDs
together decided to start next leaf the goal was really okay we see huge potential with sensors but how do you
bring sensor technology to both understand what the real challenges are and then actually define scalable
sustainable solutions that will continue to work in the long term so we started
next leaf analytics we build sensor IOT and data analytics technologies we bring
data to not only as I said understand problems but actually take a market shaping approach so we look at the whole
system we look at how do you actually solve problems how do you make big problems go away so yes we do sell
sensor devices but we also work with the W Joe and the Gates Foundation and UNICEF to start asking what are the
regulations that are needed we worked very with thousands of nurses on the ground to understand what they need so I'll
give you some examples of how we go about this but I just want to sort of
proceed all of us by saying that we're very clear that data alone is not the answer and one of the things that I love
about working with AWS and with Shree for example is that he's really clear that cloud alone is not the answer but
that it can be part of a really crucial sort of bigger approach and longer term
vision to solving big problems and that's I think what we're all here to do it's it's why we're at this public
sector conference so I'll give you a couple of examples from our work in terms of what we've been doing Oh
but just to kind of summarize for those who may not have context as I mentioned
we do work in the 80 poorest countries and what that tends to mean is that there are infrastructure gaps you know
things that we may take for granted here in terms of power availability network connectivity it cetera and that local
context becomes really important you know 1.3 billion people in India alone
and such a diverse country so really understanding the local dynamics and
cultures and customs becomes very important in any product in any solution
that's deployed often the areas are remote and you know we have to start getting creative about how we finance
things for scale because a lot of experimentation is needed a lot of patient capital is needed and and
finally maintenance is a really big issue so really thinking about how do you put in place properly incentivized
maintenance models to ensure that whatever solutions being developed is
going to sustain so these are some of the principles you could say that that we think about as we scale interventions
so the first example we'll talk about is vaccines vaccination is actually one of
the most cost effective public health interventions out there period and one
of the challenges though is that most vaccines actually have to be kept cold so if they get too hot or surprisingly
for some vaccines too cold they will lose their efficacy and so a mother will think that her child is protected but
there so the challenge is really that vaccines
are kept cold through refrigeration and that very often either because a power goes out or a refrigerator fails the
vaccines exposed to bad temperatures so a clinic like this one for example may have an old refrigerator that doesn't
work all the time the truck that delivers vaccines to this clinic may have an old refrigerator that doesn't work all the time so how do we start
helping countries make smarter better decisions about how to manage their vaccine cold chain well we worked with
Intel to build an IOT device and this is it's a small block device looks kind of
like a router you see it in the back and it monitors temperature sends it out over the network no rocket science sends
out a text message to nurses when there's a problem and we started to kind of think about layers and layers upon
layers so this was in Kenya and so we started working in one district with
about 50 clinics in Kalifa district and we started saying okay let's you know
send a text message to a nurse let's ask the nurse what are your pain points what are you trying to do how do we help you do it better and so we started crafting
the alerts the types of information the data to answer her or his key questions that they were struggling with and then
we said okay you're able to solve some of the problems but not all of them we actually did a randomized controlled
trial in Mozambique we found that when you do give when fridges call for help and you give nurses this type of
information you can get a dramatic improvement in the vaccine coaching because there's quite a bit that nurses
can do but we still weren't getting all the way there we're still seeing failures in the cold chain so whoops we
started working with district officers and with technicians we started saying okay well what are your big questions
how come how come the technician doesn't come out when the nurse calls okay it turned out that the technician didn't have the spare parts they didn't know
what type of failure it was they weren't able to plan because they didn't know what were the most common failures so we
said okay great we're gonna start you know crunching the data and help you answer those questions so we did that we helped technicians remotely diagnose
problems when they came up I'm clearly not getting a hang of the clicker sorry
and then we started looking at okay beyond that what is the why is the
Maintenance Technician not getting the funding they need in order to actually come and visit the clinic whenever they need to so then we started working with
the government and figuring out how does the government actually allocate budget budget for maintenance technicians and
we started doing this in a bunch of countries and as we did this we started finding some patterns some common
problems some common questions and so we I probably our biggest scale was in
India so the Ministry of Health in India heard about our work we helped the
government do a pilot and then they decided to put out an rfp went through a
whole multi-year competitive process and we actually ended up winning that bid to
sell the government 15,000 devices so we then won the we were the lucky winners
of the contract to go around and train thousands of nurses across the country to install these devices trained nurses
and so our technologies in about 14,000 clinics now which covers about half the
birth cohort receiving vaccines across India so massive scale we're talking
about approximately 12 million or more babies a year that receive vaccines that
are now protected with the cold trace technology so we're really excited about that potential scale but there's so much
more to be done but what we've sort of figured out now is what are the solutions that are needed and how do you
help governments start to answer and deal with some of the key questions that they have with better data along with
better training and resource mobilization and so you know we really started with the clinic with the nurses
answered their questions built our way up and what we found is that when we
stepped back and we took sort of a global look actually at the global vaccine cold-chain and now when I say global I'm talking
eighty poorest countries we found that not only are the challenges in the
country but actually the feedback loops that we were able to provide were really beneficial for some of the other market
players so fridge manufacturers you know if you're a fridge manufacturer and you're selling fridges in the 80 poorest
countries you don't have a very big markup you're doing this not out of charity but because you think it's the right thing
to do that's awesome but the way that the current market works fridge manufacturers get no feedback on their
fridges and how they're working they just get a lot of blame and pointed fingers when they don't fulfill a warranty so we started working with
fridge manufacturers to say hey how can we give you post market surveillance information that you want so now you're
incentivized to participate in this market and make better products that nurses want we started working with the
World Health Organization that develops out the standards for all these technologies whether it's fridges or a temperature monitoring we help them
actually start the market for remote temperature monitoring in clinics by developing a set of standards some so
sorry I'm going to grab something to drink
and and so what we were trying to do through building out these standards was actually build a healthy market so that
other manufacturers could come in other providers but that they would be coming into a market that was a little bit more
irrational we started working with countries to help them think about data privacy and data policy so really sort
of taking a very holistic approach to everything so I'm gonna talk a little
more briefly now about one other use case that we work in in climate change and and then I'll talk a little bit
about the technology solution so the
other area that we work in is in climate change specifically looking at how the poorest 3 billion people roughly half
the world's population cooks so cooking it turns out is one of the most basic
things that all of us do but about half the world's population actually cooks
I'm using pretty sort of prehistoric methods of burning dung and wood over
fires and this produces a lot of smoke actually leads to the deaths of close to
four million people every year this is more than the number of people that die from HIV malaria and TB combined really
massive health issue and the solution is to design better combusting cook stoves
like the one that you see on the right but the development sector has been
looking at building better cleaner cookstoves for the last roughly 50 years and when we started putting sensors on
cook stoves just to start asking let's just see what's working what's not working we found that across the board nobody
was using the clean stove and so you had all these big fancy studies coming out of all these universities saying we're
not seeing any impacts we don't know why the people's health aren't getting better and we were kind of like I think it's
because nobody's using the stove and so we threw putting sensors on stoves started doing the exact same thing that
we had done in the vaccine cold chain we started asking women what are your pain points and when you first ask somebody
you know how's their cooking going you me everybody will give you a generic answer Oh it's fine it's great I don't know I
cooked about five hours this week and what we would do is we would actually show them the dashboard I don't have a
picture of it here we said oh that's so funny because actually if you look at the dashboard you can see that you were
cooking on the clean stove for three months but you actually stopped using it what happened and then you get the real
story oh well you know the stove broke or you know my sister-in-law was using it but now that I started using it it's
too short for me you get all this sort of actual information on why people
continue to use stoves or not and so going back to sort of what I said it's not just about the data it's certainly
not just about sensors but we need a really sort of a lot of different ways of really understanding what do
end-users need and how do we kind of build solutions that will help get them that so we started kind of understanding
what stove manufacturers needed what the last mile service technician needed what did the finance Sears need and really
again took sort of this market shaping approach and clean cookstoves to really start understanding how do we design
better stoves cleaner stoves that women love so that they switch over to using something and then they can call
somebody when the stove breaks just like you and I can when our stove breaks and so it's it's been a work in progress and
one other thing I'll mention is so right this is a slightly old picture but we have a sensor device on the wall now
it's much smaller just fits directly on the stove but this sensor monitors usage of the traditional and the improved
stove sends the data to a back-end cloud and one of the things that we found was that because affordability of these
clean stoves was such a challenge for households earning less than $2 a day we
started helping women get connected with essentially climate credits so much like a big coal company gets a whole lot of
carbon based payments for switching over to a cleaner process we said why can't
women get that same thing so we helped women start getting small payments every time they use the clean stove and this
is helping women now pay a service technician to actually come fix the stove when it breaks to pay off the loan for the stove things like that so a
couple dollars a month and so essentially this is what our system
looks like all of our data goes to aw and that this is what our systems been
looking like for some years now and one of the things that we're really excited about is as we start growing right now
we're just at a couple thousand clinics less than a thousand women on the clean cooking technology but we have a lot of

hundred thousand devices roughly by 2020 and so as that growth comes while my
co-founder and I we have a great engineering team still being able to design for that kind of scale quickly and also for modularity so that it can
work across lots of different types of information system networks because dataflow flexible easy dataflow and
analysis is critical and also not only modularity but being able to design and so that when we do need machine learning
we do need AI we're ready for that we're already seeing the use cases emerge so
really kind of thinking about that next generation architecture is one of the things that we've started working with
